thread.title: No pressure, chaps: the day Theresa May went to show the Lords who’s boss
thread.title_full: No pressure, chaps: the day Theresa May went to show the Lords who’s boss

author: Michael Deacon
title: No pressure, chaps: the day Theresa May went to show the Lords who’s boss
text:
Michael Deacon Parliamentary Sketchwriter 20 February 2017 • 7:16pm Theresa May (top right) sits in the House of Lords, as peers begin their two-day debate on Brexit Credit: PA Wire 
I t isn’t normal for a prime minister to sit in the House of Lords, casting a suspicious eye over its inmates, as though she were a prison warden at visiting time. But this afternoon, this is exactly what Theresa May did. 
Just before peers were due to begin their two-day debate on Brexit , and the Government’s right to invoke Article 50, the Prime Minister swept into the chamber, and sat down on the steps in front of the empty throne. Moments later, she was joined by a henchman: David Lidington, Leader of the Commons. No doubt about it: Mrs May was here to send a message to the Lords. If any of them planned to thwart Brexit , they did so at their peril. Watch | Theresa May makes rare appearance in Lords for Brexit debate 00:40 
W hether any peers actually felt intimidated by her presence, I’m not sure. It must be said, her body language wasn’t especially daunting. Sitting there in silence, her hands clasped politely on her lap, occasionally glancing to one side and then...
